customData.content: Study population: 6,951 Western Australian mine workers between 2001-2012. Mean age: 35.8 years (SD 10.9). 90.4% men. 79.7% worked 12-hour shifts. 6,563 monitored once, 178 monitored twice, eight monitored three times, and two monitored four times.

Respiratory health surveillance was conducted using a respiratory questionnaire, lung function test, audiometric (hearing) test, and chest x-ray (in some cases). The respiratory questionnaire included questions about current respiratory symptoms in the last 3 months, including cough, phlegm, wheeze, breathlessness, and any respiratory symptom.

Occupational details: 52.4% of subjects were engaged in underground mining activities, 29.3% in service production, and 18.2% were managers. Approximately 84% of mine workers did not wear a protective mask during dusty activities, and 65.5% were non-smokers.

social_history.description: 52.4% of subjects were engaged in underground mining activities, 29.3% in service production, and 18.2% were managers.

customData.content: In 2001, the study included 410 mine workers with a mean age of 35.9 (SD 9.9). 6.6% were female and 93.4% were male. 19.5% were managers, 25.9% were in surface production, and 54.6% were in underground mining. 89.0% did not wear a mask, while 11.0% did.

In 2002, the study included 558 mine workers with a mean age of 36.7 (SD 10.3). 6.3% were female and 93.7% were male. 17.0% were managers, 23.8% were in surface production, and 59.1% were in underground mining. 88.9% did not wear a mask, while 11.1% did.

In 2003, the study included 512 mine workers with a mean age of 36.8 (SD 10.4). 7.4% were female and 92.6% were male. 20.7% were managers, 23.4% were in surface production, and 55.9% were in underground mining. 81.2% did not wear a mask, while 18.8% did.

data.content: Details of occupational activities and protective measures.
